headline.main: TOXIC CHEMICALS IN DRINKING WATER DISRUPT LIFE IN 2 SUBURBS IN MINNEAPOLIS

byline.original: BY NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr.  Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Each day Harry Werlein comes home from work carrying several large containers of water that he has purchased or obtained from his job in St. Anthony, three miles away. He has done this since July, when the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency conducted tests at his home and concluded that the well he and his family had used for 10 years was heavily contaminated with toxic chemicals. The agency also found that much of the ground water supplying this Minneapolis suburb of 23,500 people was seriously contaminated by trichlorethylene and other carcinogenic industrial byproducts that had seeped into the area's soil. Health officials from the agency say New Brighton and St. Louis Park, another Minneapolis suburb with 49,000 residents, have the most serious ground water contamination from hazardous wastes of any municipality in the state.
